I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  proposed  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  facility  will  provide  support  for 
sustainable water management of Dhaka City by focusing on restoration of severely degraded 
waterbodies in Dhaka watershed through capacity building support to two projects: (i) ongoing 
project: Dhaka Water Supply Network Improvement Project (DWSNIP),1 and (ii) ensuing project: 
Piloting of Online Continuous Effluent Monitoring System for Surface Water Quality Improvement 
in Dhaka Watershed (for approval in 2021).2  The TA is included in  Bangladesh country 
operations business plan (COBP), 2020–2022.3 The TA is aligned with ADB Strategy 2030’s 
operational priorities and will support the delivery of solutions for (i) addressing remaining poverty 
and reducing inequalities, (ii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, 
and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability,  (iii)  making  cities  more  livable,  and  (iv) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity. 
 
2.  The megacity Dhaka, established on the bank of the Buriganga River about 400 years 
ago, had the potential to grow like Venice, for a functional natural drainage system of over 65 
canals and lakes crisscrossing the city, and four rivers (i.e. Buriganga, Turag, Balu and Tongi 
Khal) encircling the city.4  Over the past few decades, the lakes and rivers of the city have been 
severely degraded and the groundwater aquifer has rapidly depleted due to high population 
growth (from 0.1 million in 1906 to 20.2 million in 2020) and unplanned urbanization. Water 
management practices have been environmentally unfriendly and unsustainable because of 
direct discharge of 2 million cubic meters of untreated wastewater from 7,000 industries, 200 
million liters of untreated municipal sewage,5 and improper disposal of 4,000 metric tons of solid 
waste from the two city corporations every day.6  As a result, surface waterbodies have been 
highly degraded and filled with solid waste. The natural drainage system has also collapsed due 
to illegal encroachment of 43 of the 65 major drainage canals, rivers, and ponds. 
 
3.  Dhaka City began sourcing public water supply from the Buriganga River since 1874 
before  slowly  transitioning  to  groundwater  to  meet  demand.  With  the  increased  demand, 
Shitalakhya River was included to supplement water supply.7 However, as the surface water 
sources around the city become unsafe and untreatable, groundwater has become the prime 
supply source as the reserve was abundant and of good quality, while the surface water was 
deteriorating.  
 
4.  Dhaka  City  extracts  87%  of  its  water  supply  from  groundwater  aquifers.  Increased 
dependency on groundwater has led to a rapid fall of groundwater table by 2-3 meters per year, 
putting the city at the risk of subsidence (footnote 7). The natural process of groundwater 
recharge is very slow due to increased impervious built-up area and thick impermeable clay 
cover on the Dupi Tila aquifers. Lateral inflow from existing surface waterbodies, such as ponds, 
 
1 ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the People’s 
Republic of Bangladesh for the Dhaka Water Supply Network Improvement Project. Manila. 
2 ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Bangladesh, 2021 – 2023. Manila. 
3 The TRTA was first included in the Country Operations Business Plan for Bangladesh (2020 – 2022), August 2019. 
4 DWASA. 2014. Water Supply Master Plan for Dhaka City. Final report. Dhaka.  
5 Hasan et al. 2019. Water Pollution in Bangladesh and its Impacts on Public Health, Heliyon, 5: 2019. 
6 Suraiya Yasmin and Md Imranur Rahman. 2017. A Review of Solid Waste Management Practice in Dhaka City, 
Bangladesh.  International Journal of Environmental Protection and Policy. Vol. 5 (2):19-25. 
7 F. J. Chowdhury, Z. U. Ahmad, and H. Aalderink. 2019. Protecting the Meghna River: A Sustainable Water Resource 
for Dhaka. Manila: ADB.

2 
 
canals, lakes, and rivers, which are degraded, is an important source for groundwater recharge.8 
Experts have suggested that to make the Dhaka City healthy, livable, and resilient, it must 
conserve 5,737 acres of water retention area, 18,782 acres of canals and rivers, and 81,000 
acres of flood-flow zones.9 
 
5.  Government has taken various initiatives including the policy measures for restoration and 
sustainable management of waterbodies in Dhaka watershed. The four rivers around Dhaka 
City—Buriganga, Balu, Shitalakhya, and Turag—were declared an Ecologically Critical Area in 
2009 due to high pollution level. The National River Conservation Commission was formed in 
2013  to  recover  the  waterbodies  from  illegal  encroachment.  Revitalization  of  waterbodies 
including sustainable management of aquifers was a priority set out in the seventh five-year plan 
(2016–2020).10  The forthcoming eighth five-year plan (2021–2025) is considering a new priority 
on the management of aquifer recharge for artificial storage of water using rainwater harvesting 
to improve the groundwater table.11 The Water Act 2013 promotes rainwater as an important 
source of safe potable water. However, government has not been able to restore the waterbodies 
and minimize surface water pollution in the city. Implementation of these priority activities 
remains a challenge as detailed studies on the current conditions or the best suitable solutions 
are yet to be explored.  
 
6.  The ongoing project. The TA facility will support in implementation of the Dhaka Water 
Supply Network Improvement Project. The outcome of the project is sustainable provision of a 
more reliable, improved, and climate-resilient water supply in Dhaka City. The three outputs are: 
(i) distribution network strengthened, (ii) sustainable managerial capacity of district metered 
areas enhanced, and (iii) capacity for quality delivery service enhanced. Output 1 is being 
achieved by renewing the entire distribution network in the Dhaka City and installation of at least 
50 new production deep tube-wells (DTWs) and regeneration of 200 existing DTWs to ensure 
more reliable and improved water supply. Output 2 will strengthen the Dhaka Water Supply and 
Sewerage Authority’s (DWASA) managerial and technical capacity to keep nonrevenue water at 
a low level. Output 3 planned for demand management, water conservation, and preparation and 
implementation of a water quality monitoring system. The total project amount is $275 million 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, of which $213.97 million has been disbursed. The project 
was approved in 2016 and is expected to close in December 2021. DWASA is the implementing 
agency. The risk categorization of the project is “complex” in the eOps. Hence, the proposed TA 
will be classified as “complex”. 
 
7.  Dhaka’s dependence on groundwater remains relevant despite the government initiatives 
for treatment of surface water to meet the demand. According to Water Supply Master Plan, 
DWASA has a zonal approach of water supply by conjunctive use of groundwater and surface 
water sources, where 30% of supply will be met by groundwater. Among the existing 11 zones 
of  the  city,  eight  zones  have  conjunctive  sources  (footnote  4).  Therefore,  availability  of 
groundwater in the Upper and Lower Dupi Tila aquifers in the Dhaka watershed needs to be 
studied well for sustainable management of this resource. This will support the government’s 
plan for conjunctive use of water from both surface and groundwater sources and is aligned with 
 
8  Trotter et al. 2017. Effects of rapid urbanization on the urban thermal between 1990 and 2011 in Dhaka megacity, 
AIMS Environmental Science, 4(1): 145 – 167. 
9  Government of People’s Republic of Bangladesh. 2015. The Dhaka Structural Plan (2016 – 2035), Rajdhani Unnayan 
Katripkkha (RAJUK). Dhaka. 
10 Government of People’s Republic of Bangladesh. 2015. Seventh Five-Year Plan (2016–2020), Accelerating Growth 
and Empowering Cities. Dhaka.  
11 The report of eighth five-year plan for 2021–2025 has not been disclosed yet.

3 
 
the government priorities in the eighth five-year plan.12 The TA facility will support the capacity 
building of the executing and implementing agencies through (i) a detailed hydrogeological study 
to assess the storage capacity of the aquifers, groundwater reserve, and recovery status (Output 
1), (ii) training (Output 2), and (iii) the preparation of a water quality monitoring system (Output 
3). These activities will contribute to the overall Outcome, Output 1, and Output 3 of the ongoing 
project. 
 
8.  The ensuing project. The TA facility will support the preparation of an ensuing project: 
Piloting of Online Continuous Effluent Monitoring System for Surface Water Quality Improvement 
in  Dhaka  Watershed,  for  approval  in  2021  with  an  expected  outcome  of  restoration  of 
waterbodies in the Dhaka watershed. 13  The proposed project will be aligned with the priorities 
of the eighth five-year plan (2021–2025). The project will implement restoration measures 
including water quality monitoring in the pollution hotspots of Dhaka watershed. The project will 
use innovative technology for online water quality monitoring which will complement output 3 of 
the Dhaka Water Supply Network Improvement Project (para. 6). As Dhaka’s polluted surface 
waterbodies, such as ponds, canals, lakes, and rivers are contributing to aquifer recharge, the 
ensuing project will further support the achievements of the Dhaka Water Supply Network 
Improvement Project through restoration of existing surface waterbodies in Dhaka watershed.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  The TA facility will deliver following three key outputs: 
 
10.  Output 1. Support hydrogeological study of Upper and Lower Dupi Tila aquifers with 
comprehensive plan for aquifer recharge. The TA will support the ongoing project through 
completion of hydrogeological study to assess the storage capacity of the aquifers, groundwater 
reserves, and recovery status.  The following activities will be conducted: (i) assess the storage 
capacity of aquifers, threats of pollution from endogenous and exogenous processes, and 
analyze  groundwater  reserve  and  recovery  status,  and  (ii)  explore  suitable  locations  and 
techniques for aquifer recharge and (iii) prepare a comprehensive plan for artificial aquifer 
recharge. As surface waterbodies contribute to aquifer recharge, water quality monitoring and 
restoration measures supported by ensuing project will directly contribute to the outcome of 
ongoing project. The TA will recruit a mix of international and national consultants through a firm 
to deliver the above activities, and they will also help to build the capacity by conducting training 
and raising awareness on demand management, water conservation, and pollution of water 
resources.  
 
11.  Output 2. Prepare comprehensive water quality monitoring plan for restoration of 
waterbodies  in  Dhaka  watershed.14 The  TA  will  support  the  ensuing  project  through 
preparation of comprehensive water quality monitoring plan including measures for restoration 
of waterbodies in Dhaka watershed.  The following activities will be conducted: (i) assess supply 
augmentation potentials of available surface waterbodies that are partially or entirely within 
Dhaka City by detailed mapping, (ii) prepare a list of waterbodies with restoration potential 
focusing on all season storage enhancement, groundwater recharge, and enhanced ecosystem 
services to be supported under the project, (iii) pollution mapping including pollution levels of 
 
12 The study findings will lead to an investment project that will be included in the upcoming country operations business 
plan (COBP), which will lead to sustainable water management, better water quality and environment, and livable 
cities. This is also a priority area for the Government of Bangladesh, and the Government has requested for ADB’s 
assistance in addressing these issues in the Dhaka watershed. 
13 The project for $10 million COL is listed firm for 2021 in the COBP, Bangladesh, 2021–2023. 
14 The project will finance innovative technology for online water quality monitoring.

4 
 
waterbodies, quality of receiving influents, and sources for both surface water and groundwater, 
(iv) identify and evaluate suitable restoration measures including technical and nature-based 
solutions for pollution prevention and reduction, and flow augmentation, and (v) develop a 
mechanism  for  online  water  quality  monitoring.  A  team  of  consultants  will  prepare  a 
comprehensive plan for water quality monitoring through the activities as above, for both surface 
water and groundwater to ensure that harmful wastewater is not polluting the groundwater 
aquifers. The results will support the preparation of the ensuing project particularly in ensuring 
adherence to ADB’s due diligence15 requirements. 
 
12.  Output 3. Review policies and institutional framework to support restoration of 
degraded  waterbodies.  Considering  both  surface  water  quality  and  groundwater  supply 
augmentation, the TA will help identify the gaps and suggest policy measures in Dhaka 
watershed. Artificial aquifer recharge through various measures will be reviewed that can help 
the  ensuing  project  in  exploring  design  options  to  facilitate  the  restoration  of  surface 
waterbodies.  A  team  of  international  and  national  consultants  will  deliver  the  output  as 
envisaged. The policy analysis would bridge the capability gaps, apply best practices, and foster 
innovative solutions for restoration of waterbodies with a focus on sustainable water supply 
challenges in the urban water sector which will be utilized in the design of the ensuing project. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, 
office supplies, secretarial and coordination assistance, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA facility, in consultation with the executing and implementing 
agencies. ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, and 
procure goods. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1. 
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements

needed) will be supported by the Government.

5

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. Procurement of goods and non-consultancy services, if any, will be 
procured by following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and 
the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time).16 The 
consultants will (i) procure the goods and equipment: computers, printers, and other equipment; 
(ii) conduct studies and surveys; and (iii) awareness on conservation of water resources. TA 
implementation will be carried out through a mix of firm and international/national individual 
consultants (40 person-months). A consulting firm will be recruited through open competitive 
bidding procedures, local advertisement, and/or limited competitive bidding using quality- and 
cost-based  selection  method,  simplified  technical  proposal,  or  biodata  technical  proposal. 
Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  for  other  positions  as  needed,  following  individual 
consultant selection method, international or local advertisement, based on project requirements. 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
Bangladesh for the Restoration of Waterbodies for Sustainable Water Management in Dhaka 
Watershed, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
16 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
